title: 110_hr1376
content: The Act titled "Medicaid Foster Care Coverage Act of 2007" establishes independent foster care adolescents as a mandatory category for Medicaid coverage. The Act establishes independent foster care adolescents as a mandatory category for Medicaid coverage, with specific amendments to the Social Security Act. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding Medicaid coverage for independent foster care adolescents. Subclauses are redesignated and sections are amended to reflect changes in the Act. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve redesignating subclauses and amending sections related to Medicaid coverage for independent foster care adolescents. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve redesignating subclauses and amending sections related to Medicaid coverage for independent foster care adolescents, specifically in subsection (a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVIII) and section 1903(f)(4) of the Act. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve redesignating subclauses and amending sections related to Medicaid coverage for independent foster care adolescents. This includes changes to subsection (a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVIII) and section 1903(f)(4) of the Act. The amendments also involve updating various sections throughout the Act to reflect the new designation. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve updating sections by changing references from "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XIX)" to "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVIII)" and from "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVIII)" to "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVII)" in various subsections. The amendments to the Social Security Act involve changing references from "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XIX)" to "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVIII)" and from "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVIII)" to "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVII)" for calendar quarters starting on or after October 1, 2007. The Social Security Act requires State legislation for the plan to meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments. Failure to meet this requirement before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's session does not mean non-compliance with the Act. The State legislature must close the first regular session after the enactment of this Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
